Description: Solid-cast group-figure representing Isis nursing Horus in copper alloy; Isis represented in a seated position, her feet on a small base; she holds on her knees Horus with the left arm while presenting her left breast with the right hand to her son; she wears the Hathoric crown with uraeus; rendering quite schematic and very flat; small tang beneath base; one of the horns and part of the disc are chipped off; corroded.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), House of 'cache of bronzes' (maybe)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Several bronzes representing Isis nursing Horus were discovered in Naukratis. No less than six of them were discovered in the cache of bronzes in a building located in the southern part of the town (on this cache and its content: Petrie 1886, 41-42; Masson 2015). According to its registered date of discovery (1885), this figure could pertain to this hoard. This group-figure belongs to the type G12 in the typology of bronzes by K. Weiss (Weiss 2012, 330-331, 822-833, Pl. 56, see esp. Nr 1168 for this specimen). It became truly popular from the Late Period onwards and one of the most depicted themes in bronze statuary (for example: Grenier 2002, 51-58, pl. VIII-X; Goddio and Fabre 2008, 318-9 no. 178-180; Roeder 1956, § 303-314). Isis nursing is also a theme which is popular in other material in Naukratis (Masson forthcoming b). The very flat and crude design featured on this figure is found on other Naukratite bronzes, such as: Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.251, 86.261, 86.253 and 86.284; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-EA.616; Liverpool, World Museum 9,9,86,101.c; BM 1885,1101.568 and BM 1885,1101.91.
